zendir.simulation package

Submodules

zendir.simulation.behaviour module

class zendir.simulation.behaviour.Behaviour(context: Context, id: str, type: str = None, parent: Instance = None)

Bases: Instance

The Behaviour class can define an instance that can exist within the simulation. Behaviours can be added to both the simulation or to an object that exists. They have no physical representation (no position or rotation) and purely exist as a way to serve abstract functionality. Examples of behaviours include flight software and power modules.

get_instance_with_id(id: str, recurse: bool = False) → Instance

Returns the instance that is attached to this behaviour with the specified ID. If the instance does not exist, None will be returned. This may be a message or a child instance of some kind.

Parameters:

  • id (str) – The ID of the instance to fetch

  • recurse (bool) – Whether to look down the chain of children to find the instance

Returns:

The instance that is attached to the object with the specified ID

Return type:

Instance

async get_message(name: str) → Message

Attempts to get the message with the specified name that is attached to the behaviour. If the message does not exist, it will be created and attached to the behaviour. If the message cannot be created, an exception will be raised.

Parameters:

name (str) – The name of the message to fetch

Returns:

The message with the specified name that is attached to the behaviour

Return type:

Message

get_messages() → list[Message]

Returns all of the messages that are attached to the behaviour. This will only include the messages that have currently been fetched.

Returns:

All of the messages that are attached to the behaviour

Return type:

list[Message]

get_parent() → Instance

Returns the parent object that the behaviour is attached to.

Returns:

The parent object that the behaviour is attached to

Return type:

Object

zendir.simulation.context module

class zendir.simulation.context.Context

Bases: object

The context object contains some functions for the simulation. This can be used for passing data between different parts of the simulation, such as the simulation engine and the function library.

always_require_refresh: bool = False

Whether the context always requires a refresh, regardless of the variable data that has been changed.

get_client() → Client

Returns the client for the context.

async get_function_library() → any

Returns the function library for the context.

get_id() → str

Returns the ID of the context.

zendir.simulation.instance module

class zendir.simulation.instance.Instance(context: Context, id: str, type: str = None)

Bases: object

The instance class is a base class that is used to define any simulation object that exists within the simulation. It is able to fetch and set data on the API, invoke methods and can be tracked by the API. This class is used to define the base functionality for the other types, but should not be created by the user itself.

async get(param: str) → any

Fetches a parameter from the object that is stored in the API. This will return the parameter if it exists and will raise an exception if it does not exist. If the data has not been fetched, it will fetch the data from the API.

Parameters:

param (str) – The parameter to fetch from the object

Returns:

The parameter value from the object

Return type:

any

async get_all() → dict

Returns all of the data that is stored in the object. This will return the full dictionary of the object and will fetch the data if it has not been fetched yet.

Returns:

The full dictionary of the object

Return type:

dict

get_id() → str

Returns the unique GUID identifier of the object. This is used to identify the object in the API and is used to fetch the data from the API.

Returns:

The unique GUID identifier of the object

Return type:

str

get_instance_with_id(id: str, recurse: bool = False) → Instance

Returns the instance that is attached to this instance with the specified ID. If the instance does not exist, None will be returned. This may be a message or a child instance of some kind.

Parameters:

  • id (str) – The ID of the instance to fetch

  • recurse (bool) – Whether to look down the chain of children to find the instance

Returns:

The instance that is attached to the object with the specified ID

Return type:

Instance

async get_type() → str

Returns the type of the object that is fetched from the API. This is the full type, including the namespace and the class name. If the type has not been fetched, it will fetch it from the API.

Returns:

The type of the object

Return type:

str

async invoke(function: str, *args) → any

Invoke a function on the object that is stored in the API. This will take in the function name and the arguments to pass to the function. This will return the response from the function call, if there is a response.

Parameters:

  • function (str) – The function name to invoke on the object

  • args (any) – The arguments to pass to the function

Returns:

The response from the function call

Return type:

any

async set(**kwargs) → None

Sets the parameters of the object that is stored in the API. This will take in a dictionary of parameters and values and will update the object with the new values. This will raise an exception if the data is invalid.

Parameters:

kwargs (dict) – The parameters and values to set on the object

zendir.simulation.message module

class zendir.simulation.message.Message(context: Context, id: str, type: str = None)

Bases: Instance

The Message class is able to store a series of parameters and data associated with the particular message type. This class is a pure data class and is not able to invoke any methods.

zendir.simulation.model module

class zendir.simulation.model.Model(context: Context, id: str, type: str = None, parent: Instance = None)

Bases: Instance

The model class cannot exist in the simulation by itself, but can be used to attach to a simulation object. Each object can have up to 1 model of a specific type attach and allows for extended functionality to be added to the object.

get_instance_with_id(id: str, recurse: bool = False) → Instance

Returns the instance that is attached to this behaviour with the specified ID. If the instance does not exist, None will be returned. This may be a message or a child instance of some kind.

Parameters:

  • id (str) – The ID of the instance to fetch

  • recurse (bool) – Whether to look down the chain of children to find the instance

Returns:

The instance that is attached to the object with the specified ID

Return type:

Instance

async get_message(name: str) → Message

Attempts to get the message with the specified name that is attached to the model. If the message does not exist, it will be created and attached to the model. If the message cannot be created, an exception will be raised.

Parameters:

name (str) – The name of the message to fetch

Returns:

The message with the specified name that is attached to the model

Return type:

Message

get_messages() → list[Message]

Returns all of the messages that are attached to the model. This will only include the messages that have currently been fetched.

Returns:

All of the messages that are attached to the model

Return type:

list[Message]

get_parent() → Instance

Returns the parent object that the model is attached to.

Returns:

The parent object that the model is attached to

Return type:

Object

zendir.simulation.object module

class zendir.simulation.object.Object(context: Context, id: str, type: str = None, parent: Object = None)

Bases: Instance

The Object class is able to define an instance that can exist within the simulation. An object will have a 3D representation within the simulation and can have behaviours and models attached to it. Objects can also have children objects attached to them. Objects will always have a position and rotation within the simulation and are the main structure for simulation object.

async add_behaviour(type: str, **kwargs) → Behaviour

Adds a behaviour to the object with the specified type. The behaviour will be created and attached to the object and will be returned to the user.

Parameters:

  • type (str) – The type of the behaviour to create

  • kwargs (dict) – Optional additional data to set on the behaviour when created

Returns:

The behaviour that was created

Return type:

Behaviour

async add_child(type: str, **kwargs) → Object

Adds a child object to the object with the specified type. The child object will be created and attached to the object and will be returned to the user.

Parameters:

  • type (str) – The type of the child object to create

  • kwargs (dict) – Optional additional data to set on the child object when created

Returns:

The child object that was created

Return type:

Object

async find_behaviour_with_id(id: str, recurse: bool = True) → Behaviour

Returns the behaviour that is attached to the object with the specified ID. If the behaviour does not exist, None will be returned. This will also look down the chain of instances to find the behaviour, if specified.

Parameters:

  • id (str) – The ID of the behaviour to fetch

  • recurse (bool) – Whether to look down the chain of instances to find the behaviour

Returns:

The behaviour that is attached to the object with the specified ID

Return type:

Behaviour

async find_behaviour_with_type(type: str, recurse: bool = True) → Behaviour

Finds the first behaviour that is attached to the object of the specified type. If the type is not found, None will be returned.

Parameters:

  • type (str) – The type of the behaviour to fetch

  • recurse (bool) – Whether to search recursively through child objects

Returns:

The first behaviour that is attached to the object of the specified type

Return type:

Behaviour

async find_behaviours_with_type(type: str, recurse: bool = True) → list[Behaviour]

Finds all of the behaviours that are attached to the object of the specified type. If the type is not found, an empty list will be returned.

Parameters:

  • type (str) – The type of the behaviours to fetch

  • recurse (bool) – Whether to search recursively through child objects

Returns:

All of the behaviours that are attached to the object of the specified type

Return type:

list[Behaviour]

async find_child_with_id(id: str, recurse: bool = True) → Object

Parameters:

  • id (str) – The ID of the child object to fetch

  • recurse (bool) – Whether to look down the chain of instances to find the child object

Returns:

The child object that is attached to the object with the specified ID

Return type:

Object

async find_child_with_type(type: str, recurse: bool = True) → Object

  • recurse (bool) – Whether to search recursively through child objects

Returns:

The first child object that is attached to the object of the specified type

zendir.simulation.simulation module

class zendir.simulation.simulation.Simulation(client: Client, id: str)

Bases: Context

The Simulation class is the root object that is used to interact with the simulation. This can be used to create objects, behaviours, systems and messages within the simulation. Additionally, it can be used to track objects, query objects and save and load the state of the simulation. A simulation requires a client to be able to access the API. These clients are used to authenticate the user and ensure that the simulation is accessible.

async add_behaviour(type: str, **kwargs) → Behaviour

Adds a behaviour to the simulation with the specified type and data. This will create a behaviour within the simulation and return the behaviour that has been created. If the behaviour cannot be created, an exception will be raised. This will add the behaviour to the root of the simulation. A behaviour is a type of object that can be attached to other objects to provide additional functionality, but has no physical representation.

Parameters:

  • type (str) – The type of the behaviour to create

  • kwargs (dict) – The optional data to set on the behaviour

Returns:

The behaviour that has been created

Return type:

Behaviour

async add_message(type: str, **kwargs) → Message

Creates a message within the simulation with the specified type and data. This will create a message within the simulation and return the message that has been created. If the message cannot be created, an exception will be raised. This will add the message to the root of the simulation. A message is a type of object that can be used to communicate between objects and systems within the simulation.

Parameters:

  • type (str) – The type of the message to create

  • kwargs (dict) – The optional data to set on the message

Returns:

The message that has been created

Return type:

Message

async add_object(type: str, **kwargs) → Object

Adds an object to the simulation with the specified type and data. This will create an object within the simulation and return the object that has been created. If the object cannot be created, an exception will be raised. This will add the object to the root of the simulation. An object will always have a position and orientation in the simulation.

Parameters:

  • type (str) – The type of the object to create

  • kwargs (dict) – The optional data to set on the object

Returns:

The object that has been created

Return type:

Object

async classmethod create(client: Client) → Simulation

Creates a new simulation with the specified client. This will create a new simulation session with the API and return the simulation that has been created. If the client is invalid, an exception will be raised.

Parameters:

client (Client) – The client to access the API

Returns:

The simulation that has been created

Return type:

Simulation

async dispose() → None

Disposes of the simulation. This will dispose of the simulation and clear all objects, behaviours, systems and messages that have been created within the simulation. The simulation can no longer be used after this has been called.

async classmethod dispose_all(client: Client) → None

Disposes of all simulations that are currently running. This will dispose of all simulations and clear all objects, behaviours, systems and messages that have been created within the simulations. The simulations can no longer be used after this has been called.

Parameters:

client (Client) – The client to access the API

async find_behaviour_with_id(id: str) → Behaviour

Attempts to find a behaviour in the simulation with a specified ID. This will look through all behaviours that exist and will attempt to find one that has been created.

Parameters:

id (str) – The ID of the behaviour to get

Returns:

The behaviour that has been found

Return type:

Behaviour

async find_instance_with_id(id: str) → Instance

Searches for an instance of the specified ID within the simulation. If the instance does not exist, it will not be created. If the instance cannot be created, None will be returned. This will search through all objects, behaviours, systems and messages within the simulation to find the instance.

Parameters:

id (str) – The ID of the instance to find

Returns:

The instance of the specified ID

Return type:

Instance

async find_instance_with_type(type: str) → Instance

Searches for an instance of the specified type within the simulation. If the instance does not exist, it will be created and returned. If the instance cannot be created, None will be returned. This will search through all objects, behaviours, systems and messages within the simulation to find the instance.

Parameters:

type (str) – The type of the instance to find

Returns:

The instance of the specified type

Return type:

Instance

async find_instances_with_type(type: str) → list[Instance]

Finds all instances of the specified type within the simulation. This will search through all objects, behaviours, systems and messages within the simulation to find the instances. If the instances do not exist, an empty list will be returned.

Parameters:

type (str) – The type of the instances to find

Returns:

The instances of the specified type

Return type:

list[Instance]

async find_message_with_id(id: str) → Message

Attempts to find a message in the simulation with a specified ID. This will look through all messages that exist and will attempt to find one that has been created. If the message does not exist, it will create a Python message with the ID and, provided it exists in the simulation already, the data will be fetched when used.

Parameters:

id (str) – The ID of the message to create

Returns:

The message that has been found or newly created.

Return type:

Message

async find_object_with_id(id: str) → Object

Attempts to find an object in the simulation with a specified ID. This will look through all objects that exist and will attempt to find one that has been created. If the object does not exist, it will create a Python object with the ID and, provided it exists in the simulation already, the data will be fetched when used.

Parameters:

id (str) – The ID of the object to create

Returns:

The object that has been found or newly created.

Return type:

Object

get_behaviours(recurse: bool = True) → list[Behaviour]

Returns all the behaviours that have been created within the simulation. This will return the behaviours as a list. If the recurse flag is set to true, all child behaviours of the objects will be returned as well.

Parameters:

recurse (bool) – Whether to return all behaviours of the objects

Returns:

The behaviours that have been created within the simulation

Return type:

list[Behaviour]

get_client() → Client

Returns the client that is used to access the API. This is used to authenticate the user and ensure that the simulation is accessible.

Returns:

The client that is used to access the API

Return type:

Client

async get_function_library() → System

Returns the function library for the simulation. This will return the function library that is used to access the API and authenticate the user.

Returns:

The function library for the simulation

Return type:

System

get_id() → str

Returns the ID of the simulation. This is used to identify the simulation within the API.

Returns:

The ID of the simulation

Return type:

str

get_messages(recurse: bool = True) → list[Message]

Returns all the messages that have been created within the simulation. This will return the messages as a list. If the recurse flag is set to true, all child messages of the instances will be returned as well.

Parameters:

recurse (bool) – Whether to return all messages of the instances

Returns:

The messages that have been created within the simulation

Return type:

list[Message]

get_models() → list[Model]

Returns all the models that have been created within the simulation. This will return all the models that have been created within the simulation as a list.

Returns:

The models that have been created within the simulation

Return type:

list[Model]

get_objects(recurse: bool = True) → list[Object]

Returns all the objects that have been created within the simulation. This will return the objects as a list. If the recurse flag is set to true, all children of the objects will be returned as well.

Parameters:

recurse (bool) – Whether to return all children of the objects

Returns:

The objects that have been created within the simulation

Return type:

list[Object]

async get_planet(name: str) → Object

Returns the planet with the specified name within the simulation. This will return the planet object that has been created within the simulation. If the planet does not exist, it will be created and returned. If the planet cannot be created, None will be returned.

Parameters:

name (str) – The name of the planet to get or create

Returns:

The planet with the specified name

Return type:

Object

get_root_behaviours() → list[Behaviour]

Returns all the root behaviours that have been created within the simulation. This will return all the behaviours that have been created directly within the simulation and not part of any other object. This will return the behaviours as a list.

Returns:

The root behaviours that have been created within the simulation

Return type:

list[Behaviour]

get_root_messages() → list[Message]

Returns all the root messages that have been created within the simulation. This will return all the messages that have been created directly within the simulation and not part of any other object. This will return the messages as a list.

Returns:

The root messages that have been created within the simulation

Return type:

list[Message]

get_root_objects() → list[Object]

Returns all the root objects that have been created within the simulation. This will return all the objects that have been created directly within the simulation and not part of any other object. This will return the objects as a list.

Returns:

The root objects that have been created within the simulation

Return type:

list[Object]

async get_state() → dict

Returns the state of the simulation. This will fetch the state from the API and return the state as a dictionary.

Returns:

The state of the simulation

Return type:

dict

async get_system(type: str, **kwargs) → System

Attempts to get the system with the specified type within the simulation. If the system does not exist, it will be created with the specified type and data. If the system cannot be created, an exception will be raised. This will add the system to the root of the simulation.

Parameters:

  • type (str) – The type of the system to get or create

  • kwargs (dict) – The optional data to set on the system

Returns:

The system with the specified type

Return type:

System

get_systems() → list[System]

Returns all the systems that have been created within the simulation. This will return all the systems that have been created within the simulation as a list.

Returns:

The systems that have been created within the simulation

Return type:

list[System]

async get_time() → float

Returns the current time of the simulation. This will fetch the time from the API and return the time as a floating point number.

Returns:

The current time of the simulation in seconds

Return type:

float

async get_tracking_interval() → float

Returns the current tracking interval for all the objects that have been tracked. This will return the interval in simulation seconds. The default value is 10.0 seconds.

Returns:

The interval to track the objects by in seconds

Return type:

float

is_valid() → bool

Returns whether the simulation is valid or not. This will check if the simulation ID is valid and if the client is valid. If the simulation ID is not valid, an exception will be raised.

Returns:

Whether the simulation is valid or not

Return type:

bool

async classmethod list(client: Client) → list[Simulation]

Lists all the simulations that are currently running. This will return a list of simulations that are currently running and their IDs. If the client is invalid, an exception will be raised.

Parameters:

client (Client) – The client to access the API

Returns:

The list of simulations that are currently running

Return type:

list[Simulation]

async load_state(path: str) → bool

Loads the state of the simulation from the specified path. This will load the state of the simulation from the path as a JSON file and return whether the state was loaded successfully. If the path does not exist, an exception will be raised. This will also reset and load all objects, behaviours, systems and messages within the simulation correctly, storing them into the Python module.

Parameters:

path (str) – The path to load the state of the simulation from

Returns:

Whether the state was loaded successfully

Return type:

bool

async query_dataframe(instance: Instance) → DataFrame

Queries the object within the simulation. This will query the object and return the data that has been stored for the object. This will return the data as a data frame. If there is no data for the object, or if the object has not yet been tracked, an empty data frame will be returned.

Parameters:

instance (Instance) – The instance to query within the simulation

Returns:

The data that has been stored for the object

Return type:

DataFrame

async query_object(instance: Instance) → SimulationData

Queries the object within the simulation. This will query the object and return the data that has been stored for the object. This will return the data as a data frame. If there is no data for the object, or if the object has not yet been tracked, an empty data frame will be returned. Due to the API having a maximum limit of data, this will also fetch the data in pages before pre-compiling the data into a single data frame.

Parameters:

instance (Instance) – The instance to query within the simulation

Returns:

The data that has been stored for the object

Return type:

DataFrame

async reload_data() → None

Reloads the data of the simulation. This will reload all objects, behaviours, systems and messages within the simulation correctly, storing them into the Python module. This is useful if the simulation has been modified externally and the data needs to be refreshed.

async save_state(path: str) → None

Saves the state of the simulation to the specified path. This will save the state of the simulation to the path as a JSON file. If the path does not exist, an exception will be raised.

Parameters:

path (str) – The path to save the state of the simulation to

async set_state(state: dict) → bool

Sets the state of the simulation to the specified state from a JSON object. This will also reset and load all objects, behaviours, systems and messages within the simulation correctly, storing them into the Python module.

Parameters:

state (dict) – The state to set the simulation to

Returns:

Whether the state was set successfully

Return type:

bool

async set_tracking_interval(interval: float) → None

Updates the tracking interval for all the objects that have been tracked. This will be an interval in simulation seconds and will be the same across all objects. The default value is 10.0 seconds.

Parameters:

interval (float) – The interval to track the objects by in seconds

async tick(step: float = 0.1) → None

Ticks the simulation by the specified amount of time. This will invoke the tick function on the simulation and update the time by the specified amount. If the step is not provided, the default step of 0.1 seconds will be used.

Parameters:

step (float) – The amount of time to tick the simulation by in seconds

async tick_duration(time: float, step: float = 0.1) → None

Ticks the simulation by the specified amount of time. This will invoke the tick function on the simulation and update the time by the specified amount. If the step is not provided, the default step of 0.1 seconds will be used. If the step is too small, it will do the final step with the remaining time.

Parameters:

  • time (float) – The totalamount of time to tick the simulation by in seconds

  • step (float) – The time-step of the tick, used for physics calculations in seconds

async track_object(instance: Instance, isAdvanced: bool = False) → None

Starts tracking the object within the simulation. This will start tracking the object which will store the object’s data and state every specified tick in a local database. This can be used to retrieve the object’s data at a later time.

Parameters:

  • instance (Instance) – The instance to track within the simulation

  • isAdvanced (bool) – Whether the advanced variables are also being tracked

zendir.simulation.system module

class zendir.simulation.system.System(context: Context, id: str, type: str = None)

Bases: Instance

A system is a singleton object within the simulation. It only exists once per simulation and is used to define the global state of the simulation.

get_instance_with_id(id: str, recurse: bool = False) → Instance

Returns the instance that is attached to this behaviour with the specified ID. If the instance does not exist, None will be returned. This may be a message or a child instance of some kind.

Parameters:

  • id (str) – The ID of the instance to fetch

  • recurse (bool) – Whether to look down the chain of children to find the instance

Returns:

The instance that is attached to the object with the specified ID

Return type:

Instance

async get_message(name: str) → Message

Attempts to get the message with the specified name that is attached to the system. If the message does not exist, it will be created and attached to the system. If the message cannot be created, an exception will be raised.

Parameters:

name (str) – The name of the message to fetch

Returns:

The message with the specified name that is attached to the system

Return type:

Message

get_messages() → list[Message]

Returns all of the messages that are attached to the system. This will only include the messages that have currently been fetched.

Returns:

All of the messages that are attached to the system

Return type:

list[Message]
